The wave that is reflected from the oil-water interface and then transmitted through the oil-air interface can interfere with the wave that is reflected from the air-oil interface.(b) Derive an expression for the minimum thickness <math alttext="t sub min " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>min</mi></msub></math> of the layer of oil that will result in maximum destructive interference of the two reflected waves in air. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="n sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></math>, <math alttext="n sub O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>O</mtext></msub></math>, <math alttext="n sub W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>W</mtext></msub></math>, the wavelength <math alttext="lambda" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>λ</mi></math> of the light in air, and physical constants, as appropriate.

Consider liquids with different refractive indexes <math alttext="n sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>L</mtext></msub></math> that could produce a thin film floating on the surface of water, where <math alttext="n sub L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>L</mtext></msub></math> could be now be either greater than or less than <math alttext="n sub W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>W</mtext></msub></math> − but still greater than <math alttext="n sub A equals 1.00" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>00</mn></math>.(c) On the axes in Figure <math alttext="5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn></math>, sketch a graph of <math alttext="t sub min" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>min</mi></msub></math>, the minimum liquid film thickness that results in destructive interference for reflected waves of fixed wavelength <math alttext="lambda" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>λ</mi></math> in air.

Consider a second scenario where air is replaced by a thick layer of a liquid that can float on top of the oil, and where the new liquid has an index of refraction greater than that of both the oil and water. Assume that the light wave in the oil has the same wavelength and phase as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>.(d) For the diagrams you drew in part (a), indicate one feature that would be different for the second scenario. Justify your answer.
